bibl.title: Letter from Jefferson Randolph Kean to Mazyck P. Ravenel, July 30, 1925

div1.p: Kean compliments Ravenel on his review of the Gorgas biography and presents his own view of the errors in the book.

div1.head: Letter from Jefferson Randolph Kean to Mazyck P. Ravenel, July 30, 1925
div1.opener:
July 30, 1925.
Dr. Mazyck P. Ravenel,
203 Hicks Avenue,
Columbia, Mo.
My dear Dr. Ravenel:
div1.p:
I have read with much interest and pleasure your
very -discriminating review of the Life and Work of Gorgas
by Mrs. Gorgas and Mr. Hendrick in the June number of the
American Journal of Public Health. The whole matter of
Reed's work in Havana and the practical application of it
by Gorgas is one of extreme interest to me as I was an inti-
mate friend of both men and was in daily association with
Reed during his stay in Cuba, I being at that time the Chief
Surgeon of Western Cuba under General Fitzhugh Lee whose
headquarters were at Marianao a few miles outside of Havana.
I, in common with Surgeon General Ireland and most of the
older officers of the Medical Corps, feel that this Life of
Gorgas rather encourages the prevailing tendency to forget
the basic and all important work of Reed because public
attention was naturally riveted on the splendid sanitary
triumphs which followed its application by Gorgas. Sixteen
months ago when Mr. Hendrick published in advance in the
Worlds Work the chapter “Yellow Fever Meets Its Master”, I
wrote to him at the request of the Surgeon General and Mrs.
Reed to point out the incorrectness of the statements made
on page 110 et seq. We objected to the statement that Gorgas
was the man that made clear for all time that the stegomyia
and the stegomyia only was the infecting agent as this had
been triumphantly demonstrated by Reed some months before
Gorgas began his mosquito work. I also showed the incorrect-
ness of the statement that Reed smiled at the idea of getting
rid of mosquitoes and said “It can't be done”. This con-
versation gives a dramatic element to the story but has not
the slightest foundation in fact. Reed and I and most mili-
tary sanitarians were familiar with Howard's use of kerosene
before we went to Cuba. It is a curious instance of the ten-
dency of periodical writers to value the story more than the
truth that Mr. Hendrick did not take the trouble to correct
this statement before bringing out the book.

I venture to take up your time with these matters
- 2 -
because I think that it concerns the memory of Walter
Reed to have the Chairman of the Editorial Section of
the Journal of Public Health familiar with them. As
fame is all that Reed got out of the conquest of yellow
fever, I hope that you may find time to read not only
this letter but the enclosed review of the book which
I published some months ago and which brings out some
other errors in the book although I dealt as gently
with them as possible on account of Mrs. Gorgas.
div1.closer:
Yours very sincerely, J. R. KEAN
Colonel, U.S. Army, Retired
Editor. JRK/W
